article.headline: He had $35,000 in retirement savings in March â 350 trades later and heâs apparently sitting on $1 million
article.body: Prepare for some serious trading FOMO, courtesy of Redditâs âWallStreetBetsâ community. If his detailed story is to be believed, the user, who identifies as âMori226â on the popular social-media platform, has had a spectacular run during the coronavirus pandemic, and he walked his fellow traders on Reddit through every step of his journey. âI cracked the 7-figure mark, and then some. I started with $35k in my ROTH IRA in late February/early March,â the trader wrote. He said he pulled out about $50,000 along the way. Check out:All about the Roth IRA Hereâs what his nosebleed trading climb looks like charted: How did he pull it off? Mori226 offered up some of the tips that worked best: Hold at least 50% in cash reserves at all times, donât beat yourself up on bad trades, let the winners ride, never put more than 25% in any single position and learn to cut your losses, to name just a few. âTry to stay disciplined. Learning to control. my emotions was key,â he said. âLosses donât kill options traders, calculating your alternate universe net worth on your woulda-coulda-shouldas do.â Mori226 went so far as to lay out each trade made during that stretch. Here are the biggest winners, led by huge profits betting on alternative-fuel vehicle maker Nikola Corp. NKLA, -1.36%, as well as on Amazon AMZN, +3.01% AMZN, +3.01%, Disney DIS, +1.53% and Apple AAPL, +1.74% : The trader also took some lumps, particularly on bets against the S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% : And one last bit of wisdom to impart: âLearning to get a sense of the current trend is the hardest part... Who is your best friend? The trend. Who gives you your giant pile of tendies [profits]? The trend,â he wrote, âWho buys your wife a new iMac pro? The trend. Never try to âoutsmartâ the market. Youâre going to lose you f*****g shirt.â What do his buddies on âWallStreetBetsâ make of it all? The top comment pretty much summed up the outpouring of love, appreciation and unveiled envy: âCongrats! Now f*** off.â
